data.title: Quick open now can open multiple scenes and scripts
data.body:
EditorQuickOpen can open multiple scenes and scripts, but not when using Quick Search File.." because it uses the inspector dock to open files and it probably will not work well mixing files and directories.

Closes #3240.

data.title: File.store_var() not writing data.
data.body:
It appears that File.store_var() isn't working in master. I've used the following code to test it:

``` GDScript

extends Node

func _ready():
    var new = File.new()
    if not new.file_exists("user://save_data"):
        new.open("user://save_data", File.WRITE)
        new.store_var('test')
        print('new')
        new.close()
    else:
        new.open("user://save_data", File.READ_WRITE)
        print(new.get_var())
        new.close()
```

I would have thought that I was just screwing something up, but I was using similar code in a game that I made in 1.1 stable last month, and it worked fine, and was working in master as of a few weeks ago. I made a cursory attempt to see if I could figure out what change may have done it, but no luck.

data.title: Add some joystick functions to input. Enables manipulation of mapping…
data.body:
…s at runtime

The following functions were added to `Input`:

`add_joy_mapping(String mapping, bool update_existing)` and `remove_joy_mapping(String guid)` for manipulation of gamepad mappings. 

`bool is_joy_known(int device)` defaults to true on all platforms that don't use the remapping code. Otherwise, checks whether the device is mapped.

`get_joy_guid(int device)` returns the sdl2 device guid if using remapping, defaults to "Default Gamepad"

I also documented these and the other joystick related functions. doctool updated quite a bit of things unrelated to this, I hope that's not a problem.

Also I hope the implementation is ok. I added `is_joy_known` and `get_joy_guid` to `OS` for the default variants. Platforms that use the remapping then override these to call back to InputDefault

data.title: Ability to create 3d NavigationMesh from set of points that are defined via code
data.body:
**I might be wrong** but it looks like there is no way to define 3d navigation from the code with set of connected points. If I'm correct in 2d equivalent this can by achieved with "NavigationPolygon" node functions:

```
void add_outline( Vector2Array outline )
void add_outline_at_index( Vector2Array outline, int index )
int get_outline_count() const
void set_outline( int idx, Vector2Array outline )
Vector2Array get_outline( int idx ) const
void remove_outline( int idx )
void clear_outlines()
void make_polygons_from_outlines()
```

However I never used Godot navigation system and I might be wrong. Provided sample generate navigation data from lvl mesh, while I'm exploring a possibility to create navigation data manually based on Grid informations as well as on 'helper' nodes placed in various locations from the editor. 
It also would be good it there could be an **ability to edit generated meshes programatically** (lets say some parts of my map are in gridmap and others are made in blender, it would be good if I would be able to merge their navigations into one from the code).
_Will label it to be considered in 2.1_

data.title: Allow sprite frames to be grouped
data.body:
Right now when an image is loaded as a sprite frame in an AnimatedSprite it is assigned an id number starting from 1, and the animation player references those frames by that number. When you have lots of frames(100+) and you need to insert one into a lower id it can cause you to have to reset many of your animations. A way to mitigate this would be to allow us to group sprite frames by another id number. So if I put all of my movement frames into group 1, and all of my Idle frames into group 2, adding new frames to group 1 will not effect group 2, you would only need to adjust animations associated with group 1.

For animations that already have no group they could just be auto assigned to a group 0 or 1.

data.title: TextEdit/LineEdit: Handle numpad when NumLock is disabled
data.body:
A small request from the list on #2982:

> numpad arrow/home/end/pgup/pgdn should work as usual when numlock is off
> -- grigi

data.title: No way to pass custom variables between Vertex and Fragment Shader
data.body:
Since godot shading language is quite limited in some cases, there is no way to pass custom variables between Vertex and Fragment Shader. There are predefined variables VAR1 and VAR2 ( which are vec4, but it's only two of them.
This makes writing optimized shaders impossible, since most of the calculations should be made in Vertex shader - but there is no way to pass them forward to Fragment one. Also arrays would make life a lot easier too.

data.title: Added missing onready token name
data.body: Fixes #3266

data.title: Editor crashes when adding tool keyword
data.body:
![crash](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1546044/12177682/4eb1c300-b522-11e5-895f-853bd4f6c187.gif)

Console output

```
ERROR: get_token_identifier: Condition ' tk_rb[ofs].type!=TK_IDENTIFIER ' is true. returned: StringName()
   At: modules/gdscript/gd_tokenizer.cpp:981.
```

Original script

```

extends Node

export var skeleton = @".." setget set_skeleton, get_skeleton
export var bone = 0 setget set_bone, get_bone
export var chain_length = 0 setget set_chain_length, get_chain_length
export var target = @"" setget set_target, get_target


var s = null
var t = null
var has = false

func _has():
    has = t && s && s.get_bone_name(bone)
    return has

func set_skeleton(n):
    if(typeof(n) == TYPE_NODE_PATH):
        skeleton = n
        s = get_node(skeleton)
    if(n extends Node):
        skeleton = get_path_to(n)
        s = n
    _has()
func get_skeleton():
    return s

func set_bone(n):
    bone = n
func get_bone():
    return bone

func set_chain_length(n):
    chain_length = n
func get_chain_length():
    return chain_length

func set_target(n):
    if(typeof(n) == TYPE_NODE_PATH):
        target = n
        t = get_node(target)
    if(n extends Node):
        target = get_path_to(n)
        t = n
    _has()
func get_target():
    return t

```

data.title: Incorrect control tooltip's placement
data.body:
I'm aware that there is similar issue - Issue #1445 but this is separate from scrollbar.

Essentially, if you parent a control (such as a button) underneath a node then changed the parent's position, the tooltip for button would remain the same regardless of button's or parent's position.

I was able to reproduce this in a clean project.
This is default position when creating the parent and the button (adjusting size of both nodes for clarity -- 200, 50).
![editor_normal](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5606120/12172694/6ba87028-b520-11e5-8525-aee11567c80d.png)

The result: 
![game_normal](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5606120/12172715/8f26fe3e-b520-11e5-8b48-4626d52f5932.png)

However, if you decide to move the parent:
![ss 2016-01-07 at 09 18 24](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5606120/12172735/af4a3e24-b520-11e5-9996-770029c5661d.png)

You can see that the tooltip has not moved along with the parent or the button:
![ss 2016-01-07 at 09 18 30](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5606120/12172743/bfd4437a-b520-11e5-8ebb-c494f51bd5b0.png)

Thing to note: I built Godot from source using commit 1fe9f626e116d0ff2d373f54c8265f5b8c2ca833

data.body:

![bug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4701338/12163728/492bf23c-b510-11e5-9083-8f56a35a1f56.png)
https://lut.im/ZHt5f7O1sN/UMiCefso2rE93sk1.PNG

data.title: A way to better organize child nodes of YSort nodes
data.body:
Currently, if I understand correctly YSort nodes only sort direct child nodes. This can be a nightmare if you have hundreds of nodes within a single YSort node and no way to organize them. Would it be possible to add a new node that would only serve as a container within YSort nodes where their contents would be YSorted as if they were direct children of the YSort node for better organization. 

Here's what I'm thinking

> > YSort
> > 
> > > > sprite1    <---- YSorted because it is a direct child node of the YSort node
> > > > sprite2 
> > > > (New container node)
> > > > 
> > > > > > sprite3
> > > > > > sprite4      <---- Direct children of the new node (sprite3 and 4) would also be YSorted as if they were direct children of the YSort node like sprites 1-2

data.title: Fix error caused by dragging a Range property
data.body:
I used  `const char*` because of `Object::_change_notify`, and the character sequence don't need to be modified.

Closes #3196.

data.body: Closes #3195.

data.body: Fixes #3178

data.title: Make joydev build using libudev and libevdev opt-out
data.body:
(i.e. it's enabled by default, users have to specifically ask for it if they don't want gamepad support)
Follow-up on #49.

Note that right now the "gamepad" option is X11-specific, as the checks for libudev and libevdev are only done there. I also removed the "Linux" condition though, as @reduz hinted that udev and evdev should work fine on FreeBSD too.

data.title: Polygon face disappears upon changed position in the inspector
data.body:
_bugsquad edit:_
- _In presented sample the dissapering polygon is imported from obj. But the bug is still valid when using ordinary Sprite3D node._
- _It's worth to mention that those objects are not be visible in the editor even after restarting Godot._ 
- _However they are still normally visible during runtime._

---

I made face polygon from Blender and export to .obj and import into Godot
There is a test scene:
https://www.dropbox.com/s/n6vpix05xfmb9py/testMoveFace.zip?dl=0

I set some postion of face in Inspector, and then face is disappear.
For example, I set translation to (0, 0, -2) and set to (0, 0, -1), now face is gone.

I use Arch Linux, 64bit is build success.

data.title: update joystick demo with visual representation
data.body: Also used `_fixed_process()` instead of `_input()`, as we're not actually parsing any input events here but just query for the current state.

data.title: Fix uniform scaling of non-square CanvasItem nodes
data.body:
Fixes #3224.
I chose the longest side of the original node (width vs height) as the "guiding direction" to handle the ever changing drag_vector and avoid issues when a component changes sign.
